claim: If no safety car period had occurred in the Australian Grand Prix where Lewis Hamilton made his debut, he would have scored fewer points.
extra_info: first race refers to min(Year); Lewis Hamiltonrefers to the full name of the driver; Full name of the driver refers to drivers.forename and drivers.surname;
reasoning: This is a counterfactual claim. It uses hypothetical language ('If no safety car period had occurred... he would have scored fewer points'), describing an imagined alternative scenario. A database only records what actually happened, not what would have happened under different race conditions. Additionally, the database has no safety car data. Counterfactual claims are always classified as NOT ENOUGH INFO.

content.text:
I need to analyze this claim carefully before querying the database.

**Reading the claim:** "If no safety car period had occurred in the Australian Grand Prix where Lewis Hamilton made his debut, he would have scored fewer points."

This is a **counterfactual** claim. It asks about a hypothetical scenario: "If no safety car period had occurred..." and then makes an assertion about what "would have" happened. This describes an imagined alternative scenario, not something that actually occurred.

According to my classification rules, counterfactual claims that describe "what if" scenarios should ALWAYS be classified as NOT ENOUGH INFO, because a database only records what actually happened, not what would have happened under hypothetical changes.

Let me briefly verify that the database doesn't contain safety car data, just to be thorough:

input.description: List all tables in the database

content.content:
circuits              drivers               results             
constructorResults    lapTimes              seasons             
constructorStandings  pitStops              status              
constructors          qualifying          
driverStandings       races

tool_use_result.stdout:
circuits              drivers               results             
constructorResults    lapTimes              seasons             
constructorStandings  pitStops              status              
constructors          qualifying          
driverStandings       races

content.text:
There is no safety car table. Even if there were, the claim is counterfactual — it asks what **would have** happened under a different scenario.

The claim uses the classic counterfactual structure:
- "**If** no safety car period **had occurred**..." (hypothetical condition)
- "...he **would have** scored fewer points" (hypothetical consequence)

This is a textbook counterfactual/hypothetical scenario. The database records actual race results, not simulations of alternative race conditions. There is no way to verify from historical data what would have happened if race conditions had been different.

```json
{"label": "NOT ENOUGH INFO", "reasoning": "This is a counterfactual claim. It uses hypothetical language ('If no safety car period had occurred... he would have scored fewer points'), describing an imagined alternative scenario. A database only records what actually happened, not what would have happened under different race conditions. Additionally, the database has no safety car data. Counterfactual claims are always classified as NOT ENOUGH INFO."}
```
